title: Sri Lanka set Aussies 196 for ODI record
text:
Sri Lankan standout Chamari Atapattu has ensured Australia will need to work for a world record 18th consecutive ODI victory, scoring a classy century as the visitors posted 8-195 in Brisbane.

The Sri Lankan opener backed up her brilliant T20 ton against the Australians earlier in the tour by making the most of a dropped chance on 55 to anchor the visitors' innings at Allan Border Field.

Australia stalled a bright Sri Lankan start before seizing control by taking 3-2, Georgia Wareham's leg-spin proving tricky in a four-over spell that yielded 2-18.

Atapattu (103 off 124) pushed on, but the runs dried up as Megan Schutt also picked up two wickets against the world No.8 side.

Meg Lanning's side can take outright ownership of the longest women's ODI winning streak by chasing down the total and overtaking Belinda Clark's Australian side's run in the late 1990s.

Australia's men own the outright record with 21 straight ODI victories, set in 2003.

Lanning's side will match that feat if they sweep their three-game series in South Africa in March, when they next play 50-over cricket.
